revision.text:
The '''1828 Proclamation of Demarcation''' was issued by [[George Arthur]], governor of [[Tasmania]], and ordered the white colonial populations and [[Tasmanian Aboriginal]] populations be temporarily separated from each other.<ref name="Bonwick1870">{{cite book|author=James Bonwick|title=The last of the Tasmanians: or, The Black War of Van Diemen's Land|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LTwKAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA78|year=1870|publisher=Johnson Reprint Corp.|pages=78–}}</ref> Arthur clarified that the proclamation would not limit Aboriginals from traveling through Tasmania to shellfish hunting territories, provided a passport was coordinated with their leaders.<ref name="Carroll2014">{{cite book|author=Dr Khadija von Zinnenburg Carroll|title=Art in the Time of Colony|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P9CpBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA92|date=28 April 2014|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.|isbn=978-1-4094-5596-7|pages=92–}}</ref> The proclamation was justified as protecting Aboriginals from violence from colonists, and to protect the colonists from "repeated and wanton barbarous murders and other crimes" by the Aboriginals.<ref name="Morgan2003">{{cite book|author=Sharon Morgan|title=Land Settlement in Early Tasmania: Creating an Antipodean England|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bTJeskna35YC&pg=PA151|date=11 December 2003|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-52296-0|pages=151–}}</ref>
The proclamation established a line of military outposts separating the declared Aboriginal and colonial territories, which the Aboriginals were forbidden to pass.<ref name="Morgan2003"/> Tasmanian Aboriginals were pressed into remote areas of Tasmania, and eventually relocated to [[Flinders Island]]; scholar [[Rod Edmond]] notes that the pretext of "protecting" the Aboriginals served as a mechanism to clear desirable land for colonial use.<ref name="Edmond2006">{{cite book|author=Rod Edmond|title=Leprosy and Empire: A Medical and Cultural History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=15U9YIr1masC&pg=PA193|date=30 November 2006|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-139-46287-7|pages=193–}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:1828 in Australia]] [[Category:1828 documents]] [[Category:Aborigines in Tasmania]] [[Category:Anti-indigenous racism in Australia]] [[Category:History of Tasmania]] [[Category:Segregation]]

{{Infobox technology standard | title = Guidelines For Development Of Civil Aircraft and Systems | image = | caption = arp | status = | year_started = | version = | versionDate = {{Start date|2010|12}} | preview = | previewDate = | organization = [[Society of Automotive Engineers|International]] | related_standards = | abbreviation = ARP4754A | domain = Aviation | website = {{URL|www.sae.org/technical/standards/arp4754a}} }} '''ARP4754''', Aerospace Recommended Practice (ARP) ARP4754A (''Guidelines For Development Of Civil Aircraft and Systems''), is a guideline from [[SAE International]], dealing with the development processes which support [[Type certificate|certification]] of [[Avionics#Aircraft avionics|Aircraft systems]]. Revision A was released in December 2010. It was recognized by the FAA in AC 20-174 published November 2011.<ref>{{cite manual | last = S–18 | first = | author-link = | coauthors = | title = Guidelines for Development of Civil Aircraft and Systems | section = | sectionurl = | version = | publisher = [[SAE International]] | year = 2010 | url = http://standards.sae.org/arp4754a | format = | id = ARP4754A | isbn = | accessdate = | quote = | page = | pages = | ref = }} </ref> [[EUROCAE]] jointly issues the document as ED–79.
==Objectives of the document== The Aerospace Recommended Practice (ARP) is a guideline for development of civil aircraft and systems with an emphasis on safety aspects. Revision A is a substantial rewrite of the document which describes the safety process as a part of an Integrated Development Process. A significant new section is devoted to the process of determining Development Assurance Level (DAL) which determines the rigor of complex hardware and software development and verification activities.
It is intended to be used in conjunction with SAE [[ARP4761]] (still under revision in December 2013) and is supported by other aviation standards such as [[RTCA, Incorporated|RTCA]] [[DO-178C]]/[[DO-178B]] and [[DO-254]].
This guideline addresses Functional Safety and design assurance processes. DAL allocation pertaining to functional failure conditions and hazard severity are assigned to help mitigate risks. Functional Hazard Analyses / Assessments are central to determining hazards and assigning DAL, in addition to requirements based testing and other verification methods. This guideline concerns itself with Physical (item) DAL and Functional (software/systems integration behavior) DAL and the Safety aspects of systems for the whole life-cycle for systems that implement [[Avionics#Aircraft avionics|aircraft functions]].
==History== ARP4754 was defined in the context of [[Type certificate|aircraft certification]], in particular Part 25 Sections 1301 and 1309 of harmonized [[civil aviation]] regulations for [[transport category]] [[airplane]]s. These are found in the U.S. [[Federal Aviation Administration|FAA]] [[Federal Aviation Regulations]] (FAR) at 14 CFR 25.1309 and the corresponding European [[Joint Aviation Authorities|JAA]] [[Joint Aviation Requirements]] (JAR), which have been replaced by [[European Aviation Safety Agency|EASA]] certification standards. FAA Advisory Circular [[AC 25.1309-1]]A, ''System Design and Analysis'', explained certification methodology for Part 25 Section 1309.<ref>{{cite manual | author = ANM-110 | title = System Design and Analysis | section = | sectionurl = | version = | publisher = [[Federal Aviation Administration]] | year = 1988 | url = http://www.faa.gov/documentLibrary/media/Advisory_Circular/AC%2025.1309-1A.pdf | format = pdf | id = Advisory Circular AC 25.1309-1A | accessdate = 2011-02-20 | quote = | page = | pages = | ref = }}</ref>
In May 1996, the FAA Aviation Rulemaking Advisory Committee (ARAC) was tasked with a review of harmonized FAR/JAR 25.1309, AC 1309-1A, and related documents, and to consider revision to AC 1309-1A incorporating recent practice, increasing complex integration between aircraft functions and the systems that implement them,<ref>ARP4754A, p. 7</ref> and the implications of new technology. This task was published in the Federal Register at 61 FR 26246-26247 (1996-05-24). The focus was to be on safety assessment and fault-tolerant critical systems.
In a parallel effort, SAE published ARP4754 in November 1996. In 2002 ARAC submitted to the FAA a draft Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM) and draft revision AC 1309-1B (the draft ARSENAL version) recognizing the role of ARP4754 in complex system certification.<ref>{{cite manual | author = ARAC Systems Design and Analysis Harmonization Working Group | title = Task 2 – System Design and Analysis Harmonization and Technology Update | section = | sectionurl = | version = | publisher = [[Federal Aviation Administration]] | year = 2002 | url = http://www.faa.gov/regulations_policies/rulemaking/committees/arac/media/tae/TAE_SDA_T2.pdf | format = pdf | id = | accessdate = 2011-02-20 | quote = | page = | pages = | ref = }}</ref> This draft remains unreleased, but ARP4754 became broadly recognized as an appropriate standard for aircraft system development and certification. The corresponding EASA Acceptable Means of Compliance AMC 25.1309 (included as a section of CS-25) does recognize ARP4754/ED–79.
The FAA and EASA have both subsequently recognized ARP4754/ED–79 as valid for certification of other aircraft categories, and for specific systems such as avionic databuses.
ARP4754A and ED79A were released by SAE and EUROCAE in December 2010. The document title has changed to ''Guidelines For Development Of Civil Aircraft and Systems''. ARP4754A recognizes AMC 25.1309 (published in 2003) and AC 25.1309-1B-Arsenal draft. This revision expands the design assurance concept for application at the aircraft and system level and standardizes on the use of the term development assurance. As a consequence, Functional Development Assurance Level (FDAL) is introduced for aircraft and systems concerns and the term Design Assurance Level has been renamed Item Development Assurance Level (IDAL).<ref>ARP4754A, pp. 7-8</ref> Furthermore, the addition of definitions for ''Error'', ''Failure'', and ''Failure Condition'' are acknowledge as derived from AMC 25.1309.<ref>ARP4754A, pp. 11</ref> The qualitative and quantitative classification of failure conditions by severity and probability now used by ARP4754A<ref>ARP4754A, p. 34</ref> and ARP4761<ref>{{cite manual | last = S–18 | title = Guidelines and methods for conducting the safety assessment process on civil airborne systems and equipment | publisher = [[Society of Automotive Engineers]] | year = 1996 | url = http://www.sae.org/technical/standards/ARP4761 | id = ARP4761 | page=9 }}</ref> are defined in AMC 25.1309/AC 25.1309–1B-Arsenal draft.
==See also== *[[AC 25.1309-1]] *[[DO-254]] *[[DO-178C]] and [[DO-178B]] *[[ARP4761]] *[[ISO 26262]] *[[Hazard analysis]] *[[Safety engineering]] *[[Avionics]] *[[Type certificate]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://standards.sae.org/arp4754a/ ARP4754A page on SAE website]
{{SAE International}}
[[Category:Handbooks and manuals]] [[Category:Engineering literature]] [[Category:Avionics]]

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{COI|date=May 2017}} {{notability|date=May 2017}} {{primary sources|date=May 2017}} }} The '''Arabic Speech Corpus''' is a [[Modern Standard Arabic]] (MSA) speech corpus for speech synthesis. The corpus contains phonetic and orthographic transcriptions of more than 3.7 hours of MSA speech aligned with recorded speech on the phoneme level. The annotations include word stress marks on the individual phonemes.<ref name="HALABI2016">{{cite thesis |last=Halabi |first=Nawar |year=2016 |title=Modern Standard Arabic Phonetics for Speech Synthesis |url=http://en.arabicspeechcorpus.com/Nawar%20Halabi%20PhD%20Thesis%20Revised.pdf |type=PhD Thesis |publisher=[[University of Southampton]], School of Electronics and Computer Science}}</ref>
The Arabic Speech Corpus was built as part of a doctoral project by [[Nawar Halabi]] at the [[University of Southampton]] funded by [http://www.microlinkpc.com/ MicroLinkPC] who own an exclusive license to commercialise the corpus, but the corpus is available for strictly non-commercial purposes through the [http://www.arabicspeechcorpus.com official Arabic Speech Corpus website]. It is distributed under the [[Creative Commons]] Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.<ref name="OX2016">{{cite |year=2016 |title=Arabic Speech Corpus |url=http://ota.ox.ac.uk/desc/2561 |type=Web Page |publisher=[[University of Oxford]] }}</ref>
==Purpose== The corpus was mainly built for speech synthesis purposes, specifically [[Speech Synthesis]], but the corpus has been used for building HMM based voices in Arabic. It was also used to automatically align other speech corpora with their phonetic transcript and could be used as part of a larger corpus for training speech recognition systems.<ref name="HALABI2016">{{cite thesis |last=Halabi |first=Nawar |year=2016 |title=Modern Standard Arabic Phonetics for Speech Synthesis |url=http://en.arabicspeechcorpus.com/Nawar%20Halabi%20PhD%20Thesis%20Revised.pdf |type=PhD Thesis |publisher=[[University of Southampton]], School of Electronics and Computer Science}}</ref>
==Contents== The package contains the following: * 1813 .wav files containing spoken utterances. * 1813 .lab files containing text utterances. * 1813 .TextGrid files containing the phoneme labels with time stamps of the boundaries where these occur in the .wav files. These files can be opened using Praat software. * phonetic-transcript.txt which has the form "[wav_filename]" "[Phoneme Sequence]" in every line. * orthographic-transcript.txt which has the form "[wav_filename]" "[Orthographic Transcript]" in every line. Orthography is in Buckwalter Format which is friendlier where there is software that does not read Arabic script. It can be easily converted back to Arabic. * There is an extra 18 minutes of fully annotated corpus (separate from above but with the same structure as above) which was used to evaluated the corpus (see PhD thesis).
The corpus was also used to prove that using automatically extracted, orthography-based stress marks<ref name="HALPERN2009">{{cite conference |url=http://www.cjk.org/cjk/arabic/an_paper.pdf |title=Word Stress and Vowel Neutralization in Modern Standard Arabic |first=Jack |last=Halpern |year=2009 |conference=2nd International Conference on Arabic Language Resources and Tools |location= Cairo}}</ref> improve the quality of speech synthesis in MSA.
==See also== * [[Comparison of datasets in machine learning]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.arabicspeechcorpus.com The Arabic Speech Corpus official website] * [https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/4.0/ The Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License]
{{Corpus linguistics}}
[[Category:Speech synthesis]] [[Category:Speech processing]] [[Category:Corpora]] [[Category:Datasets in machine learning]] [[Category:Arabic-language computing]]

revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=July 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} [[File:Association for Scottish Literary Studies (logo).jpg|thumb|right|upright|ASLS logo]] The '''Association for Scottish Literary Studies''' (ASLS) is a Scottish educational [[charitable organization|charity]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Scottish Charity Register|publisher=Office of the Scottish Charity Regulator|url=http://www.oscr.org.uk/CharityIndexDetails.aspx?id=SC006535|accessdate=16 March 2008}}</ref> founded in 1970 to promote and support the teaching, study and writing of [[Scottish literature]]. Its founding members included the Scottish literary scholar [[Matthew McDiarmid]] (1914–1996). Originally based at the [[University of Aberdeen]], it moved to its current home within the [[University of Glasgow]] in 1996. In November 2015, ASLS was allocated £40,000 by the [[Scottish Government]] to support its work providing teacher training and classroom resources for schools.<ref>{{cite web|title=Supporting Scottish Studies|publisher=The Scottish Government|url=http://news.scotland.gov.uk/News/Supporting-Scottish-Studies-1f10.aspx|accessdate=7 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307190819/http://news.scotland.gov.uk/News/Supporting-Scottish-Studies-1f10.aspx|archive-date=7 March 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
ASLS's main field of activity is [[publishing]], and the organisation is a member of [[Publishing Scotland]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Association for Scottish Literary Studies |publisher=Publishing Scotland |url=http://www.publishingscotland.org/what-we-do/members/publisher-members/association-for-scottish-literary-studies/ |accessdate=23 October 2016}}</ref>
==Publications==
===Periodicals=== ASLS produces [[Periodical literature|periodicals]], including ''Scottish Literary Review'' (formerly ''Scottish Studies Review''), a [[peer review]]ed [[academic journal|journal]] of Scottish literature and [[cultural studies]]; ''Scottish Language'', a peer reviewed journal of [[Languages of Scotland|Scottish languages]] and [[linguistics]]; ''The International Journal of Scottish Literature'', a free online peer reviewed journal (2006–2013); and ''The Bottle Imp'', a free online [[ezine]] (named after [[The Bottle Imp|the short story]] by [[Robert Louis Stevenson]]). Since June 2013, ''Scottish Literary Review'' has been included in [[Project MUSE]]'s Premium Collection of journals.<ref>{{cite web|title=Scottish Literary Review|publisher=Project MUSE|url=http://staging01.muse.jhu.edu/journals/scottish_literary_review/|accessdate=28 March 2014}}</ref>
===Books===
====Annual Volumes==== Since 1971 ASLS has republished a number of [[out of print]] Scottish texts in their ''Annual Volumes'' series (45 volumes by 2016). Titles in the series include reprints of 18th- and 19th-century fiction, anthologies of Scottish drama, editions of poetry and collections of other writings. Two ASLS Annual Volumes have won [[Saltire Society]] '''Research Book of the Year''' awards: ''The Poems of [[William Dunbar]]'', edited by Priscilla Bawcutt (1998), and [[Sorley MacLean]]'s ''Dàin do Eimhir'', edited by [[Christopher Whyte (writer)|Christopher Whyte]] (2002).<ref>{{cite web|title=Research Book Awards|publisher=Saltire Society|url=http://www.saltiresociety.org.uk/research.htm|accessdate=5 March 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090224100609/http://saltiresociety.org.uk/research.htm| archivedate= 24 February 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
====International Companions to Scottish Literature==== In 2015, ASLS launched the ''International Companions to Scottish Literature'' series, co-edited by [[Professor Ian Brown|Ian Brown]] and [[Thomas Owen Clancy]].<ref>{{cite web|title=International Companions to Scottish Literature|publisher=ASLS|url=http://asls.arts.gla.ac.uk/Companions.html|accessdate=7 March 2016}}</ref> Titles in the series to date include ''The International Companion to [[Lewis Grassic Gibbon]]'',<ref>{{cite web|title=The International Companion to Lewis Grassic Gibbon|publisher=ASLS|url=http://asls.arts.gla.ac.uk/IC1.html|accessdate=7 March 2016}}</ref> ''The International Companion to [[Edwin Morgan (poet)|Edwin Morgan]]'',<ref>{{cite web|title=The International Companion to Edwin Morgan|publisher=ASLS|url=http://asls.arts.gla.ac.uk/IC2.html|accessdate=7 March 2016}}</ref> ''The International Companion to [[Poetry of Scotland|Scottish Poetry]]'',<ref>{{cite web|title=The International Companion to Scottish Poetry|publisher=ASLS|url=http://asls.arts.gla.ac.uk/IC3.html|accessdate=7 March 2016}}</ref> ''The International Companion to [[James Macpherson]] and [[Ossian|The Poems of Ossian]]'',<ref>{{cite web|title=The International Companion to James Macpherson and The Poems of Ossian|publisher=ASLS|url=http://asls.arts.gla.ac.uk/IC4.html|accessdate=21 February 2017}}</ref> and ''The International Companion to [[John Galt (novelist)|John Galt]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=The International Companion to John Galt|publisher=ASLS|url=http://asls.arts.gla.ac.uk/IC5.html|accessdate=23 May 2017}}</ref>
====New Writing Scotland==== Since its first issue in 1983, many contemporary Scottish writers have had early work published in ASLS's annual [[anthology]] of new short fiction and poetry, ''New Writing Scotland'', including [[Leila Aboulela]],<ref>{{cite book |title=Friends and Kangaroos: New Writing Scotland 17 |authors=Moira Burgess and Donny O'Rourke (eds) |year=1999 |publisher=ASLS |location=Glasgow |isbn=0-948877-41-3 |pages=1–6}}</ref> [[Lin Anderson]],<ref>{{cite book |title=Full Strength Angels: New Writing Scotland 14 |authors=Kathleen Jamie and James McGonigal (eds) |year=1996 |publisher=ASLS |location=Glasgow |isbn=0-948877-31-6 |pages=1–7}}</ref> [[Iain Banks]],<ref>{{cite book |title=New Writing Scotland 1 |authors=Alexander Scott and James Aitchison (eds) |year=1983 |publisher=ASLS |location=Aberdeen |isbn=0-9502629-4-3 |pages=32}}</ref> [[Polly Clark]],<ref>{{cite book |title=The Rooftop Busker: New Writing Scotland 33 |authors=Gerry Cambridge and Diana Hendry (eds) |year=2015 |publisher=ASLS |location=Glasgow |isbn=978-1-906841-24-9 |pages=20–23}}</ref> [[Anne Donovan (author)|Anne Donovan]],<ref>{{cite book |title=Full Strength Angels: New Writing Scotland 14 |authors=Kathleen Jamie and James McGonigal (eds) |year=1996 |publisher=ASLS |location=Glasgow |isbn=0-948877-31-6 |pages=20–23}}</ref> [[Janice Galloway]],<ref>{{cite book |title=New Writing Scotland 7 |authors=Edwin Morgan and Hamish Whyte (eds) |year=1989 |publisher=ASLS |location=Aberdeen |isbn=0-948877-06-5 |pages=60–68}}</ref> [[Jane Harris (writer)|Jane Harris]],<ref>{{cite book |title=Scream If You Want To Go Faster: New Writing Scotland 9 |authors=Janice Galloway and Hamish Whyte (eds) |year=1981 |publisher=ASLS |location=Aberdeen |isbn= 0-948877-12-X |pages=70–77}}</ref> [[Gail Honeyman]],<ref>{{cite book |title=Songs of Other Places: New Writing Scotland 32 |authors=Gerry Cambridge and Zoë Strachan (eds) |year=2014 |publisher=ASLS |location=Glasgow |isbn=978-1-906841-19-5 |pages=53–61}}</ref> [[A L Kennedy]],<ref>{{cite book |title=Pig Squealing: New Writing Scotland 10 |authors=Janice Galloway and Hamish Whyte (eds) |year=1992 |publisher=ASLS |location=Aberdeen |isbn=0-948877-15-4 |pages=78–82}}</ref> [[James Meek (author)|James Meek]],<ref>{{cite book |title=New Writing Scotland 7 |authors=Edwin Morgan and Hamish Whyte (eds) |year=1989 |publisher=ASLS |location=Aberdeen |isbn=0-948877-06-5 |pages=133–148}}</ref> [[Ian Rankin]],<ref>{{cite web|title=An Afternoon|author=Ian Rankin|publisher=The Short Story|url=http://www.theshortstory.org.uk/stories/index.php4?storyid=9|accessdate=16 March 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080225011821/http://www.theshortstory.org.uk/stories/index.php4?storyid=9| archivedate= 25 February 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> [[James Robertson (novelist)|James Robertson]],<ref>{{cite web|title=The Locus Index to Science Fiction 2001|publisher=Locus Online|url=http://www.locusmag.com/index/yr2001/d60.htm#A3392|accessdate=16 March 2008}}</ref> [[Suhayl Saadi]],<ref>{{cite book |title=The Glory Signs: New Writing Scotland 16 |authors=Kathleen Jamie and Donny O'Rourke (eds) |year=1998 |publisher=ASLS |location=Glasgow |isbn=0-948877-37-5 |pages=131–140}}</ref> [[Ali Smith]],<ref>{{cite book |title=New Writing Scotland 2 |authors=Alexander Scott and James Aitchison (eds) |year=1984 |publisher=ASLS |location=Aberdeen |isbn=0-9502629-5-1 |pages=8–11}}</ref> [[Chiew-Siah Tei]],<ref>{{cite book |title=Making Soup in a Storm: New Writing Scotland 24 |authors=Valerie Thornton and Brian Whittingham (eds) |year=2006 |publisher=ASLS |location=Glasgow |isbn=978-0-948877-72-8 |pages=92–97}}</ref> [[Irvine Welsh]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Writing Scotland|publisher=BBC|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/scotland/arts/writingscotland/learning_journeys/scotlands_languages/irvine_welsh/|accessdate=16 March 2008}}</ref> and others. ''New Writing Scotland'' is part-funded by [[Creative Scotland]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Awards Made - May 2017|publisher=Creative Scotland|url=http://www.creativescotland.com/__data/assets/excel_doc/0016/42073/5-Awards-Made-May-2017-v3.xlsx|accessdate=4 May 2018}}</ref>
====Occasional Papers==== The ASLS ''Occasional Papers'' series publishes essays and [[monographs]] on Scottish literary and linguistic topics, often based on papers presented at ASLS [[Academic conference|conferences]]. The most recent edition in this series, number 22, is entitled ''Empires and Revolutions: [[Robert Bontine Cunninghame Graham|Cunninghame Graham]] and His Contemporaries''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Empires and Revolutions|publisher=ASLS|url=http://asls.arts.gla.ac.uk/Empires_and_Revolutions.html|accessdate=6 October 2017}}</ref>
====Scotnotes==== ASLS publishes the ''Scotnotes'' series of [[study guide]]s to Scottish writers and their literary works. There are currently thirty-four titles in this series, on authors ranging from late medieval poets such as [[William Dunbar]] and [[Robert Henryson]] to contemporary writers such as [[Iain Banks]], [[Liz Lochhead]] and [[Ian Rankin]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Scotnotes|publisher=ASLS|url=http://asls.arts.gla.ac.uk/Scotnotes.html|accessdate=22 July 2013| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090331235709/http://www.arts.gla.ac.uk/ScotLit/ASLS/Scotnotes.html| archivedate= 31 March 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
====Other titles==== In May 2010, in partnership with the [[Loch Lomond and The Trossachs National Park]], ASLS published an illustrated edition of [[Sir Walter Scott|Sir Walter Scott's]] narrative poem ''[[The Lady of the Lake (poem)|The Lady of the Lake]]'', to mark the 200th anniversary of the original publication.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Lady of the Lake|publisher=ASLS|url=http://asls.arts.gla.ac.uk/LotL.html|accessdate=9 July 2010}}</ref>
In June 2011, with financial support from the [[Gaelic Books Council]], ASLS published a new edition of [[Sorley MacLean]]'s ''An Cuilithionn/The Cuillin''.<ref>{{cite web|title=An Cuilithionn 1939|publisher=ASLS|url=http://asls.arts.gla.ac.uk/Cuillin.html|accessdate=16 June 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110609185713/http://www.arts.gla.ac.uk/ScotLit/ASLS/Cuillin.html| archivedate= 9 June 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
In February 2013, ASLS hosted the inaugural Dr Gavin Wallace Fellowship, set up by Creative Scotland "to enable a writer to take time out of their usual environment to embark upon a year-long literary adventure to develop their practice".<ref>{{cite web|title=The Dr. Gavin Wallace Fellowship|publisher=Creative Scotland|url=http://www.creativescotland.com/what-we-do/latest-news/archive/2013/02/the-dr-gavin-wallace-fellowship/|accessdate=18 August 2015}}</ref> [[Kirsty Logan]] was selected to be the first recipient of the Fellowship,<ref>{{cite web|title=Kirsty Logan named inaugural Dr. Gavin Wallace Fellow|publisher=Creative Scotland|url=http://www.creativescotland.com/what-we-do/latest-news/archive/2013/08/kirsty-logan-named-inaugural-dr.-gavin-wallace-fellow|accessdate=18 August 2015}}</ref> and on 10 August 2015 ASLS published her collection of short stories ''A Portable Shelter''.<ref>{{cite web|title=ASLS: A Portable Shelter|publisher=ASLS|url=http://asls.arts.gla.ac.uk/A_Portable_Shelter.html|accessdate=18 August 2015}}</ref>
==Exhibitions== Since 2004, ASLS has mounted the '''Scottish Writing Exhibition''' at the [[Modern Language Association|Modern Language Association of America]]'s annual conventions in the USA, most recently in [[New York City]] in January 2018,<ref>{{cite web|title=List of 2018 Exhibitors|publisher=MLA|url=https://www.mla.org/Convention/MLA-2018/MLA-Exhibit-Hall/List-of-2018-Exhibitors|accessdate=15 January 2018}}</ref> and plans to attend the 2019 event in [[Chicago]]. In August 2008 the Scottish Writing Exhibition was on display at the biannual [[European Society for the Study of English]] (ESSE) conference in [[Aarhus]] in [[Denmark]].
==Presidents== A number of literary scholars have held the presidency of the ASLS: *John MacQueen (1970–1973) *Tom Dunn (1973–1976) *Alexander Scott (1976–1979) *[[David Daiches]]<ref>{{cite book |title=David Daiches: a Celebration of His Life and Work |editor1-first=William |editor1-last=Baker |editor2-first=Michael |editor2-last=Lister |year=2007 |publisher=Sussex Academic Press |location=Eastbourne, UK |isbn=978-1-84519-159-7 |page=70 }}<!--|accessdate=11 May 2009 --></ref> (1979–1984) *Tom Crawford (1984–1989) *[[Maurice Lindsay]]<ref>{{cite news | first=Alan | last=Riach | title=Obituary: Maurice Lindsay | url=https://www.theguardian.com/theguardian/2009/may/12/maurice-lindsay-obituary-poet-scotland/ | publisher=[[The Guardian]]| date=12 May 2009 | accessdate=1 June 2009}}</ref> (1989–1993) *John Blackburn (1993–1994) *David Robb (1994–1998)<ref>{{cite web|title=David Robb : English : University of Dundee|publisher=[[University of Dundee]]|url=https://www.dundee.ac.uk/english/staff/details/david-robb.php|accessdate=22 March 2017}}</ref> *Dorothy McMillan (1998–2002) *Alan MacGillivray (2002–2006) *[[Alan Riach]] (2006–2010) *Ian Brown (2010–2015) *Alison Lumsden (2015–)
==Awards== To date, two ASLS Annual Volumes have won [[Saltire Society]] [[Saltire Society Literary Awards|Research Book of the Year]] awards: ''The Poems of [[William Dunbar]]'', edited by Priscilla Bawcutt (1998); and [[Sorley MacLean]]'s ''Dàin do Eimhir'', edited by [[Christopher Whyte (writer)|Christopher Whyte]] (2002).<ref>{{cite web|title=Research Book Awards|publisher=Saltire Society|url=http://www.saltiresociety.org.uk/research.htm|accessdate=5 March 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090224100609/http://saltiresociety.org.uk/research.htm| archivedate= 24 February 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
In 2011, the ASLS's edition of Sorley MacLean's ''An Cuilithionn/The Cuillin'' was shortlisted for the Saltire Society [[Saltire Society Literary Awards|Scottish Book of the Year]] award.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Saltire Society: 2011 Shortlist |publisher=Saltire Society |url=http://www.saltiresociety.org.uk/4282 |accessdate=21 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120118095117/http://www.saltiresociety.org.uk/4282 |archivedate=18 January 2012 }}</ref>
Also in 2011, along with [[VisitScotland]] and the University of Glasgow, the ASLS co-produced ''Literary Scotland: A Traveller's Guide''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Literary Scotland: A Traveller's Guide|publisher=ASLS|url=http://asls.arts.gla.ac.uk/Literary_Scotland.html|accessdate=11 July 2012}}</ref> In October 2011, this publication won the [[Chartered Institute of Public Relations]] Scotland Gold Award for Best Publication.<ref>{{cite web|title=Scotland: CIPR|publisher=CIPR|url=http://www.cipr.co.uk/content/events-awards/pride-awards/pride-awards-results-2011/scotland|accessdate=11 July 2012}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Scottish literature]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.asls.org.uk/ Association for Scottish Literary Studies] *{{Scottish charity|SC006535}} * [http://www.scottishwriting.org.uk/ Scottish Writing Exhibition] * [http://www.ijsl.stir.ac.uk ''The International Journal of Scottish Literature''] * [http://www.thebottleimp.org.uk ''The Bottle Imp'' ezine]

revision.comment: A policy based consensus has been reached to remove this section from professional wrestling articles [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#Should the "In wrestling" section be removed from professional wrestling articles|Here]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox professional wrestler | name = Buddy Roberts | names = Buddy Roberts
Dale Valentine
Dick Roberts | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Dale Hey | height = {{height|ft=5|in=11}}{{cite book | author=Greg Oliver and Steve Johnson | title= The Pro Wrestling Hall of Fame: The Tag Teams | publisher=ECW Press | chapter= The Next 5: The Hollywood Blonds | pages= 98–100 | year=2005| isbn=978-1-55022-683-6}} | weight = {{convert|225|lb|kg|abbr=on}} | birth_date = May 16, 1947 | birth_place = [[Oklahoma]], United States | death_date = {{death date and age|2012|11|26|1947|5|16}} | death_place = [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], United States | billed = "Badstreet U.S.A." | death_cause = [[Pneumonia]] | trainer = [[Ivan Koloff]] | debut = 1965 | retired = 1988 }} '''Dale Hey''' (May 16, 1947 – November 26, 2012) was an American [[professional wrestling|professional wrestler]], better known by his [[ring name]], '''Buddy Roberts'''. Primarily a [[tag team]] wrestler, Roberts is known for his appearances as one of [[The Hollywood Blonds]] in the 1970s and as one of [[The Fabulous Freebirds]] in the 1980s. He was inducted into the [[Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame and Museum|Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame]] in 2015 and the [[WWE Hall of Fame]] in 2016.{{cite book|author=Harris M. Lentz III|title=Obituaries in the Performing Arts, 2012|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LO3ymSmVrlMC&pg=PA245|date=24 April 2013|publisher=McFarland|isbn=978-1-4766-0385-8|pages=245}}{{cite book|author=Kristian Pope|title=Tuff Stuff Professional Wrestling Field Guide: Legend and Lore|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GTBIFdm525YC&pg=PA370|date=28 August 2005|publisher=Krause Publications|isbn=0-89689-267-0|pages=370}} ==Early life== Hey was born in [[Oklahoma]] on May 16, 1947. He was raised in [[Vancouver|Vancouver, British Columbia]] in Canada. ==Professional wrestling career== ===Early career (1965–1970)=== Hey was trained as a professional wrestler by [[Ivan Koloff]].{{cite book|author=Greg Klein|title=The King of New Orleans: How the Junkyard Dog Became Professional Wrestling's First Black Superhero|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HHhrb3EvVWUC&pg=PA66|date=18 April 2014|publisher=ECW Press|isbn=978-1-77090-224-4|pages=66}} He debuted in 1965 under the ring name "Dale Valentine", billed as being the younger brother of [[Johnny Valentine]]. At the tail end of the 1960s, he was working as a preliminary wrestler in the [[American Wrestling Association]] (AWA). ===The Hollywood Blonds (1970–1977)=== {{also|The Hollywood Blonds}} In 1970, Hey was brought into the Oklahoma-based [[NWA Tri-State]] promotion by [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Book|booker]] [[Bill Watts]]. Watts had intended to create a new tag team comprising Jack Donovan and veteran journeyman Jerry Brown. After Donovan left the promotion following a dispute with Watts, Watts hired Hey in his place. Hey was renamed "Buddy Roberts" and began teaming with Brown as [[The Hollywood Blonds]].{{cite book|author1=[[Bill Watts]]|author2=Scott Williams|title=The Cowboy and the Cross: The Bill Watts Story: Rebellion, Wrestling and Redemption|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AOTLLXwEBXkC&pg=PA97|date=January 2006|publisher=ECW Press|isbn=978-1-55022-708-6|pages=97}} In 1972, [[Oliver Humperdink]] began managing The Hollywood Blonds.{{cite book|author1=Patric Laprade|author2=Bertrand Hebert|title=Mad Dogs, Midgets and Screw Jobs: The Untold Story of How Montreal Shaped the World of Wrestling|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ey8bluWM_m4C&pg=PA1940|date=14 March 2013|publisher=ECW Press|isbn=978-1-77090-296-1|pages=1,940}} The team of Brown and Roberts won numerous regional tag team titles across the [[United States]] throughout the 1970s.[http://www.wrestlingdata.com/index.php?befehl=tagteams&team=1916 Hollywood Blondes title listing, from WrestlingData.com] ===The Fabulous Freebirds (1979–1988) === {{also|The Fabulous Freebirds}} After splitting from Brown, Roberts joined with [[Michael Hayes (wrestler)|Michael Hayes]] and [[Terry Gordy]] to form [[The Fabulous Freebirds]]. Again, Bill Watts played a major role in this decision. Hayes and Gordy had been teaming together in various promotions in the Mid-South and Southeastern regions of the United States for several years, but Watts was not as impressed with Hayes's in-ring work as he was with his skills on the microphone. His original plan was to have Gordy and Roberts as the actual tag team, with Hayes as their manager. Except for a high-profile stint in 1980 in Mid-South Wrestling (formed by Watts the previous year after breaking away from NWA Tri-State) with Hayes and Gordy as the Freebirds, Roberts did not work full-time with the team until they joined World Class Championship Wrestling (see below). Hey later became known as Buddy "Jack" Roberts, due to his penchant for drinking [[Jack Daniel's]] whiskey.{{cite book | author=Greg Oliver and Steve Johnson | title= The Pro Wrestling Hall of Fame: The Tag Teams | publisher=ECW Press | chapter= Top 20: 7 The Fabulous Freebirds | pages= 46–51 | year=2005| isbn=978-1-55022-683-6}} ====World Class Championship Wrestling/World Wrestling Federation==== The Fabulous Freebirds won several titles and moved on to [[World Class Championship Wrestling]] in late 1982 and began a high-profile feud with the [[Von Erich family]]. They wrestled [[David Von Erich]], [[Kerry Von Erich]], [[Mike Von Erich]] and [[Kevin Von Erich]] numerous times in 1986.[http://www.wrestlingdata.com/index.php?befehl=bios&wrestler=2095&bild=1&details=7&liga=172&jahr=1986 Buddy Roberts' 1986 WCCW matches, from WrestlingData.com] Roberts also had a long-standing feud with Von Erich ally [[Chris Adams (wrestler)|Chris Adams]], which lasted on and off for more than five years.[http://www.wrestlingdata.com/index.php?befehl=konst&letter1=B&wrestler1=1917&letter2=C&wrestler2=5134&letter3=&wrestler3=0&letter4=&wrestler4=0&matchtyp=0&anzeige=matches Roberts matches with Chris Adams, from WrestlingData.com] Roberts' most famous singles angle came in WCCW in 1983, and involved the invention of what the Freebirds referred to as "Freebird Hair Removal Cream". The angle culminated in a hair match between Roberts and [[Iceman Parsons]] on June 17.[http://www.wrestlingdata.com/index.php?befehl=shows&sort=liga&show=55388 WCCW Wrestling Star Wars results, from WrestlingData.com] Roberts seemingly won the match via tight-pulling, but the decision was reversed and the match restarted. In the fracas, Roberts' head was lathered in the hair removal cream. At subsequent events, Roberts wore a wig, kept in place by boxing headgear. In 1984, Roberts and the Freebirds had a short stint in the [[WWE|World Wrestling Federation]], mainly competing in six-man tag matches.[http://www.wrestlingdata.com/index.php?befehl=bios&wrestler=2095&bild=1&details=7&liga=3&jahr=1984 Roberts' 1984 WWF matches, from WrestlingData.com] Here, they were managed by [[Cyndi Lauper]]'s manager, [[David Wolff]]. They left the promotion when WWF officials stated their intention to split the team up. At the AWA's [[SuperClash]] in 1985, Roberts helped Hayes and Gordy defeat [[The Road Warriors]] for the [[AWA World Tag Team Championship]], but the decision was later reversed. ====Universal Wrestling Federation==== In early 1986, The Freebirds went to the [[Universal Wrestling Federation (Bill Watts)|Universal Wrestling Federation]], where Roberts won the UWF Television Championship on September 28. He lost it to Savannah Jack on November 9.[http://www.wrestlingdata.com/index.php?befehl=titles&titel=874 UWF Television Title history, from WrestlingData.com] ====Return to World Class Championship Wrestling==== In 1987, The Freebirds split up and reformed. Roberts and Gordy turned on Hayes and teamed with [[Iceman Parsons]] to feud with Hayes and the Von Erichs. Gordy eventually left Roberts to rejoin Hayes. The feud ended in late 1988 when Hayes and Gordy left for the [[National Wrestling Alliance|NWA]]'s [[Jim Crockett Promotions]], and Roberts acted as a manager to the [[Samoan Swat Team]] before he retired from wrestling. Roberts also had a short feud with World Class referee David Manning, which included several gimmick matches, such as Roberts wrestling with one arm tied behind his back. Manning, who was touted as an accomplished amateur wrestler by the promotion to compensate for the obvious size difference between the two, won most of the matches on a fluke. ===Late career=== Roberts managed Hayes and [[Jimmy Garvin]] in one match against [[Steve Armstrong]] and [[Tracy Smothers]] in [[World Championship Wrestling]] (WCW) on September 5, 1990. He came out of retirement on April 2, 1993 for the [[Global Wrestling Federation]]'s Kerry Von Erich Memorial Show, and teamed with Michael Hayes (with [[Skandor Akbar]] in their corner), losing to Kevin Von Erich and Chris Adams (with Fritz Von Erich in their corner).{{cite web| url=http://members5.boardhost.com/barneyspage/msg/1317071238.html| title=Barneys Room Global:1993-Pt.1| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304023227/http://members5.boardhost.com/barneyspage/msg/1317071238.html| archivedate=2016-03-04| df=}} Roberts later developed [[Head and neck cancer|throat cancer]], and had surgery to treat it. He was quoted as saying "Don't smoke. I think the reason this happened to me is because I was smoking too much. I recommend to anyone who smokes to quit now. It is hard, but it is worth it."{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/superstars/wherearetheynow/roberts|title= Where are they now? "Buddy Roberts" |publisher=[[WWE]]|work=[[WWE]].com|author=DeFino, Lennie|accessdate=January 14, 2017|date=May 16, 2007}} ==Death== Roberts died on November 26, 2012, at the age of 65, of pneumonia.[http://www.411mania.com/wrestling/news/264841/Kevin-Von-Erich-Comments-on-Buddy-Roberts/-Passing.htm Kevin von Erich comments on Buddy Roberts' passing][http://www.prowrestling.net/artman/publish/WWE/article10028579.shtml Jim Ross comments on Roberts' death] On April 2, 2016, Roberts was posthumously inducted into the [[WWE Hall Of Fame]] by his son, Buddy "Jack" Roberts Jr. as part of [[The Fabulous Freebirds]]. ==Championships and accomplishments== *'''[[Cauliflower Alley Club]]''' **Other honoree ([[Cauliflower Alley Club#2003|2003]]) *'''[[Continental Wrestling Association]]''' **[[AWA Southern Tag Team Championship]] ([[AWA Southern Tag Team Championship#Title history|1 time]]) - with Jerry Brown{{cite book | author=Royal Duncan & Gary Will | title=Wrestling Title Histories | publisher=Archeus Communications | year=2006|edition=4th | chapter= AWA Southern Heavyweight Title| pages=189–191| isbn=0-9698161-5-4}} *'''[[Championship Wrestling from Florida]]''' **[[NWA Florida Tag Team Championship]] ([[NWA Florida Tag Team Championship#Title history|2 times]]) - with Jerry Brown{{cite book | author=Royal Duncan & Gary Will | title=Wrestling Title Histories | publisher=Archeus Communications | year=2006|edition=4th | chapter= NWA Florida Tag Team Title| pages=160–161| isbn=0-9698161-5-4}} *'''[[Jim Crockett Promotions|Mid-Atlantic Championship Wrestling]]''' **[[NWA Mid-Atlantic Tag Team Championship]] ([[NWA Mid-Atlantic Tag Team Championship#Title history|1 time]]) - with Jerry Brown{{cite book | author=Royal Duncan & Gary Will | title=Wrestling Title Histories | publisher=Archeus Communications | year=2006|edition=4th | chapter= NWA Mid-Atlantic Tag Team Title| pages=115| isbn=0-9698161-5-4}} *'''[[New Japan Pro Wrestling]]''' **[[NWA North American Tag Team Championship (Los Angeles/Japan version)|NWA North American Tag Team Championship ''(Los Angeles/Japan version)'']] ([[NWA North American Tag Team Championship (Los Angeles/Japan version)#Title history|1 time]]) - with Jerry Brown{{cite book | author=Royal Duncan & Gary Will | title=Wrestling Title Histories | publisher=Archeus Communications | year=2006|edition=4th | chapter= NWA North American Tag Team| pages=294| isbn=0-9698161-5-4}} *'''[[World Class Championship Wrestling|NWA Big Time Wrestling / World Class Championship Wrestling / World Class Wrestling Association]]''' **[[NWA Texas Heavyweight Championship]] ([[NWA Texas Heavyweight Championship#Title history|1 time]]){{cite book | author=Royal Duncan & Gary Will | title=Wrestling Title Histories | publisher=Archeus Communications | year=2006|edition=4th | chapter= NWA Texas Heavyweight Title| pages=268–269| isbn=0-9698161-5-4}} **[[WCWA World Six-Man Tag Team Championship|NWA World Six-Man Tag Team Championship ''(Texas version)'']] ([[WCWA World Six-Man Tag Team Championship#Title history|6 times]]) - with [[Michael Hayes (wrestler)|Michael Hayes]] & [[Terry Gordy]] (5) and [[Iceman Parsons]] & Terry Gordy (1) {{cite book | author=Royal Duncan & Gary Will | title=Wrestling Title Histories | publisher=Archeus Communications | year=2006|edition=4th | chapter= NWA World Six-Man Tag Team Title| pages=271–272| isbn=0-9698161-5-4}} **[[WCCW Television Championship]] ([[WCCW Television Championship#Title history|1 time]]){{cite book | author=Royal Duncan & Gary Will | title=Wrestling Title Histories | publisher=Archeus Communications | year=2006|edition=4th | chapter= WCCW Television Title| pages=270–271| isbn=0-9698161-5-4}} **[[WCWA World Six-Man Tag Team Championship]] ([[WCWA World Six-Man Tag Team Championship#Title history|1 time]]) - with Michael Hayes & Terry Gordy 1 *'''[[National Wrestling Alliance|NWA Hollywood Wrestling]]''' **[[NWA Americas Tag Team Championship]] ([[NWA Americas Tag Team Championship#Title history|4 times]]) - with Jerry Brown{{cite book | author=Royal Duncan & Gary Will | title=Wrestling Title Histories | publisher=Archeus Communications | year=2006|edition=4th | chapter= NWA Americas Tag Team Title| pages=296–297| isbn=0-9698161-5-4}} *'''''[[Pro Wrestling Illustrated]]''''' **PWI ranked him #'''167''' of the top 500 singles wrestlers of the "[[PWI Years]]" in 2003 *'''[[Universal Wrestling Federation (Bill Watts)|NWA Tri-State / Mid-South Wrestling Association / Universal Wrestling Federation]]''' **[[NWA United States Tag Team Championship (Tri-State version)|NWA United States Tag Team Championship ''(Tri-State version)'']] ([[NWA United States Tag Team Championship (Tri-State version)#Title history|3 times]]) - with Jerry Brown{{cite book | author=Royal Duncan & Gary Will | title=Wrestling Title Histories | publisher=Archeus Communications | year=2006|edition=4th | chapter= NWA Tri-State Tag Team Title| pages=235| isbn=0-9698161-5-4}} **[[UWF World Tag Team Championship|Mid-South Tag Team Championship]] ([[UWF World Tag Team Championship#Title history|1 time]]) - with [[Terry Gordy]]{{cite book | author=Royal Duncan & Gary Will | title=Wrestling Title Histories | publisher=Archeus Communications | year=2006|edition=4th | chapter= Mid-South Tag Team Title| pages=232–233| isbn=0-9698161-5-4}} **[[UWF World Television Championship]] ([[UWF World Television Championship#Title History|1 time]]){{cite book | author=Royal Duncan & Gary Will | title=Wrestling Title Histories | publisher=Archeus Communications | year=2006|edition=4th | chapter= UWF World Television Title| pages=234–235| isbn=0-9698161-5-4}} *'''[[Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame and Museum|Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame]]''' **Class of 2015{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/2014/11/26/22096551.html|title=Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame Class of 2015 announced|last=Oliver|first=Greg|date=2014-11-26|accessdate=2014-11-28|work=Slam! Sports|publisher=[[Canadian Online Explorer]]}} *'''Southern Pro Wrestling''' **SPW Arkansas Heavyweight Championship (1 time) *'''[[Southwest Championship Wrestling]]''' **[[SCW Southwest Heavyweight Championship|SCW Southwest Television Championship]] ([[SCW Southwest Heavyweight Championship#Title history|2 times]]){{cite book | author=Royal Duncan & Gary Will | title=Wrestling Title Histories | publisher=Archeus Communications | year=2006|edition=4th | chapter= SCW Southwest Television Title| pages=276| isbn=0-9698161-5-4}} **[[SCW Southwest Heavyweight Championship]] ([[SCW Southwest Heavyweight Championship#Title history|1 time]]){{cite book | author=Royal Duncan & Gary Will | title=Wrestling Title Histories | publisher=Archeus Communications | year=2006|edition=4th | chapter= SCW Southwest Heavyweight Title| pages=276| isbn=0-9698161-5-4}} * '''[[WWE]]''' ** [[WWE Hall of Fame]] (Class of 2016) *'''[[Wrestling Observer Newsletter awards]]''' **[[Wrestling Observer Newsletter awards#Match of the Year|Match of the Year]] (1984) with Terry Gordy and Michael Hayes vs. [[the Von Erichs]] ([[Kerry Von Erich|Kerry]], [[Kevin Von Erich|Kevin]], and [[Mike Von Erich|Mike]]) in an [[Professional wrestling match types#No Disqualification match|Anything Goes match]] on July 4 **[[Wrestling Observer Newsletter awards#Tag Team of the Year|Tag Team of the Year]] (1980) with Terry Gordy as [[Fabulous Freebirds|The Fabulous Freebirds]] **[[Wrestling Observer Newsletter Hall of Fame]] ([[Wrestling Observer Newsletter Hall of Fame#2005 inductees|Class of 2005]]) – as part of [[The Fabulous Freebirds]] 1During the Freebirds' 5th reign, the reign carried over after the title's name was changed to the WCWA World Six-Man Tag Team Championship since they were the champions during the time the name change occurred. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==See also== {{Portal|Professional wrestling}} * [[The Fabulous Freebirds]] * [[The Hollywood Blonds]] ==External revision.text: #REDIRECT [[CRV7]] {{R to initialism}}

{{refimprove|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox publisher | name = Chilton | image = | caption = | parent = [[Cengage Learning]] and [[Haynes Publishing Group]] | status = | traded_as = | predecessor = | founded = 1904 | founder = George Buzby, C. A. Musselman, and James Artman | successor = | country = United States | headquarters = | distribution = | keypeople = | publications = Books, databases | topics = Automotive | genre = | imprints = | revenue = | owner = | numemployees = | url = }}
'''Chilton Company''' (AKA Chilton Printing Co., Chilton Publishing Co., Chilton Book Co. and Chilton Research Services) is a former publishing company, most famous for its trade magazines, and automotive manuals. It also provided conference and market research services to a wide variety of industries. Chilton grew from a small publisher of a single magazine to a leading publisher of business-to-business magazines, consumer and professional automotive manuals, craft and hobby books, and a large, well-known marketing research company.
In the early years, its flagship magazine was ''Iron Age''. In 1955, Chilton's profit reached $1 million for the first time, of which ''Iron Age'' accounted for $750,000. By 1980, ''Iron Age'''s revenue and status had declined due to the reduction in the size of the US metalworking manufacturing industry, and ''Jewelers Circular Keystone'' captured the position of Chilton's most profitable magazine. While Chilton had leading magazines in several different industries, the Chilton name is most strongly associated with the consumer and professional automotive manuals, which [[Cengage Learning]] continues to license or publish.
== History == The company's origins go back to July 1896, and the first issue of ''Cycle Trade Journal'', edited by [[James Artman]] who became the first president of the future Chilton Company. In 1899 the magazine changed its name to ''Cycle & Automobile Trade Journal''. A 1900 magazine masthead listed Musselman & Buzby as the exclusive advertising representatives for ''Cycle & Automobile Trade Journal''. In 1900 [[George Buzby]], [[C. A. Musselman]], and James Artman merged their companies to form the ''Trade Advertising & Publishing Co''. The new company expanded into automotive catalogs, booklets, circulars, and posters.
The company selected the name ''Chilton'' from the [[Mayflower]]s passenger list. The earliest known use of the corporate name ''Chilton Company'' was in 1904. It appears on a [[corporate seal]] that reads "Chilton Company of Pennsylvania, incorporated March 31, 1904." In 1907, the three partners purchased a printing company that they renamed the ''Chilton Printing Company'', only publicly adopting the name ''Chilton Company'' in 1910.
In March 1911, Chilton published the first issue of ''Commercial Car Journal''. In February 1912, they renamed the original ''Cycle & Automobile Trade Journal'' to ''Automobile Trade Journal'', and eventually merged it into [[Motor Age]] magazine.
In 1923, the partners sold Chilton to [[United Publishers Corp]] of New York for $1,635,000, and Artman and Buzby retired. In the same year, Chilton opened a new printing plant at 56th and Chestnut Streets in Philadelphia. This location became the Chilton Company corporate headquarters in the late 1940s.
Shortly after the purchase, United Publishers merged their [[Class Journal]] subsidiary and Chilton into what became known as the ''Chilton Class Journal Co'', with C. A. Musselman as its president. This merger brought several future flagship magazines (such as [[Iron Age]], [[Motor Age]], [[Dry Goods Economist]], [[Jewelers Circular]], [[Hardware Age]], and [[Automotive Industries (magazine)|Automotive Industries]]) into the Chilton stable of magazines.
In 1934, the company underwent a complete reorganization. [[J. Howard Pew]] provided an infusion of cash that saved the company from bankruptcy, in exchange for a majority of the stock. All subsidiaries merged into one company and incorporated in the state of [[Delaware]] as ''Chilton Company''. While the cash infusion from J. Howard Pew saved the company, it became the single biggest inhibitor to its growth, as Pew did not permit Chilton to seek outside funding for acquisitions. As a result, Chilton Company's growth over the next thirty years lagged behind competitors like [[McGraw Hill]] and [[Penton]].
George Buzby's son [[G. C. (Carroll) Buzby]] became president of Chilton in the early 1950s and remained the Chief Executive Officer until he retired in the late 1960s. George C. Buzby died of cancer in 1970.
In 1979, the [[American Broadcasting Company]] purchased the Chilton Company and made it an operating unit of [[ABC Publishing]]. In 1985, [[Capital Cities Communications|Capital Cities]] purchased ABC, and in 1996 the [[Walt Disney Company]] purchased Capital Cities/ABC. Over-extended financially by its acquisition of Capital Cities ABC, Disney had to sell assets to reduce its debt—and Chilton, despite its status and recognition as an excellent business-to-business magazine publisher, was not considered a core business. Disney therefore decided to split up and sell the Chilton Company profit centers to multiple buyers: * [[Reed Elsevier]] purchased the Chilton building and the magazine, trade show, and research division for $444 million in 1997.<ref>{{Cite news| issn = 0099-9660| last = Service| first = AP-Dow Jones News| title = Reed Elsevier Buys Chilton From ABC for $447 Million| work = Wall Street Journal| accessdate = 2016-07-12| date = 1997-06-23| url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB867056358398821000}}</ref> The research division was sold on to [[Taylor Nelson Sofres|Taylor Nelson AGB]] in 1998.<ref>[http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Cahners+sells+Chilton+Research+Services+to+Taylor+Nelson+AGB.-a020575815 Cahners sells Chilton Research Services to Taylor Nelson AGB]</ref> * The [[Hearst Corporation]] purchased the Chilton professional automotive assets. In December 1999, a court injunction, effective for three years, divided those assets and rights between Hearst and Nichols Publishing. * [[Nichols Publishing]] purchased the Chilton consumer automotive group assets and brand.
In 2001, Nichols sold the do-it-yourself automotive print manuals to [[Haynes Publishing Group]] (publishers of [[Haynes Manual]]s), while retaining licensing rights to the Chilton do-it-yourself brand for print products for 10 years.
In 2003, Nichols sold the remaining automotive assets to [[Thomson Learning]]. In 2007 Thomson Learning became [[Cengage Learning]]. In 2011, Cengage Learning became owner of the Chilton brand for do-it-yourself print manuals as well. Cengage Learning continues to publish or license the professional and consumer automotive products and assets.
== Offices ==
After acquisition by United Publishers in 1923, the corporate office moved to New York City. In 1955, all former United Publishers magazines and their staffs relocated from New York City to the corporate headquarters at 56th and Chestnut Streets in Philadelphia. In 1968 Chilton moved their corporate offices to Decker Square in Bala Cynwyd, Pennsylvania. This served as temporary headquarters until 1972 when Chilton moved into its new corporate headquarters building in Radnor, Pennsylvania.
== Automobile repair manuals ==
Chilton currently publishes hundreds of automobile repair manuals that cover thousands of models. Here are some of the manufacturers covered in the Chilton do-it-yourself library:<ref>{{cite web|title=Chilton Online Auto Repair Manuals|url=http://www.chilton.cengage.com|publisher=Cengage Chilton|accessdate=2013-06-20}}</ref>
{{col-begin}} {{col-break}} *[[Acura]] *[[Alfa Romeo]] *[[American Motors]] *[[Audi]] *[[Austin]] *[[BMW]] *[[Buick]] *[[Cadillac]] *[[Chevrolet]] *[[Chrysler]] *[[DeSoto (automobile)|DeSoto]] *[[Dodge]] *[[Fiat]] *[[Ford]] *[[Frazer (automobile)|Frazer]] *[[Geo (automobile)|Geo]] *[[GMC (automobile)|GMC]] *[[Honda]] {{col-break}} *[[Hyundai]] *[[Infiniti]] *[[International Automobile Company|International]] *[[Jaguar Cars|Jaguar]] *[[Jeep]] *[[Kaiser Motors|Kaiser]] *[[Kia Motors|Kia]] *[[Lexus]] *[[Lincoln (automobile)|Lincoln]] *[[Mazda]] *[[Mini]] *[[Mitsubishi]] *[[Mercedes-Benz]] *[[Mercury (automobile)|Mercury]] *[[MG Cars|MG]] *[[Nash Motors|Nash]] *[[Nissan]] {{col-break}} *[[Oldsmobile]] *[[Opel]] *[[Peugeot]] *[[Plymouth (automobile)|Plymouth]] *[[Pontiac]] *[[Porsche]] *[[Renault]] *[[Saab Automobile|Saab]] *[[Saturn Corporation|Saturn]] *[[Scion (automobile)|Scion]] *[[Studebaker]] *[[Subaru]] *[[Toyota]] *[[Triumph Motor Company|Triumph]] *[[Volkswagen]] *[[Volvo]] *[[Mitsubishi]] {{col-end}}
== Fiction publishing == After many years of publishing business-to-business magazines and automotive manuals, Chilton acquired the trade publisher Greenberg: Publisher in 1958.<ref>{{Cite book| publisher = Gale Research Co| isbn = 978-0-8103-1724-6| pages = 164| editors = Peter Dzwonkoski (ed.)| last = Heininger| first = Joseph| title = American literary publishing houses, 1900-1980. Trade and paperback| chapter = Greenberg: Publisher| location = Detroit, Mich| series = Dictionary of literary biography| date = 1986}}</ref> Chilton published the celebrated [[science fiction]] novels ''[[Dune (novel)|Dune]]'' by [[Frank Herbert]] ([[1965 in literature|1965]]),<ref>{{citation|title=It's the birthday of Frank Herbert...|work=[[The Writer's Almanac]]|date=October 8, 2013|url=http://writersalmanac.publicradio.org/index.php?date=2013/10/08|publisher=[[American Public Media]]}}</ref> and ''[[The Witches of Karres]]'' ([[1966 in literature|1966]]) by [[James H. Schmitz]]. Each was nominated for a [[Hugo Award for Best Novel]] in its respective year, and ''Dune'' won the award. ''Dune'' became the first of a series of six novels by Frank Herbert, which were followed by many books, mostly prequels, by his son, [[Brian Herbert]], and [[Kevin J. Anderson]], an unrelated but experienced author. Of these books, Chilton only published the first.
==See also== * [[Clymer repair manual]] * [[Haynes Manuals]]

revision.text:
{{for|the bishop of Carthage|Cyprian}} [[File:Cyprianus.jpg|thumb|right|This published ''Cyprianus'' from 1916 calls itself a "dream and fortunetelling book", and it also promises an [[astrology|astrological]] [[almanac]] from [[Tycho Brahe days|Tycho Brahe]].]] '''''Cyprianus''''' is a name given in [[Scandinavia]]n traditions of [[folk magic]] to the "black book" ("''Svarteboken"''): a [[grimoire]] or manuscript collection of [[spell (magic)|spells]]; and by extension to the magical tradition that these spells form a part of. There is no standard text called "Cyprianus"; it was a general label given to a collection of spells.Mary Rustad, ''The Black Books of Elverum'' (Galde Press, 1999; {{ISBN|1-880090-75-9}}) Manuscripts called or referring to Cyprianus had a dark reputation; in some versions, you obtained the text by renouncing your baptism and devoting yourself to [[Satan]]. The common people's opinion of the book was that it was a standard grimoire concerned with the summoning of [[demon]]s and spirits. [[Christian ministry|Ministers]] were often thought to have obtained it through their studies at university; it is not coincidence that ministers' wives often functioned as [[folk healer]]s in rural communities.[[Kathleen Stokker]], ''Remedies and rituals: folk medicine in Norway and the New Land'' (Minnesota Historical Society, 2007; {{ISBN|0-87351-576-5}}); ch. 5, "The Pastor as Doctor" Like many such texts, it is bound to its owner and hard to get rid of; it will not burn nor be destroyed by water, and attempting to discard it will only result in its supernatural return.''[[Salmonsens Konversationsleksikon]]'' (1915-1930), v. 5, pp. [http://runeberg.org/salmonsen/2/5/0387.html 386-387] These compilations nevertheless were widely circulated among the [[cunning folk]] of Scandinavia, who in a rural land with few [[physician]]s were the [[folk healer]]s sought out by ordinary people beset by injury or illness. ==Cyprianus== "Cyprianus" is the name frequently given to the compiler or author of the spells contained in the tradition. A variety of stories are told concerning the identity of this Cyprianus. Saint [[Cyprian and Justina|Cyprian of Antioch]] was a bishop and martyr in early [[Christianity]]. In the Middle Ages, a variety of legends attached to his name, including a tradition that he practiced magic before his conversion, and as such was the author of a magical textbook. In another medieval tradition, Cyprianus was a sorcerer who sought to seduce St. [[Cyprian and Justina|Justina]], but was foiled and converted when she made the sign of the cross and he followed suit, freeing himself from the power of the devil. The sorcerer and the historical bishop were likely conflated in later legend.Ludwig Radermacher, ''Griechische Quellen zur Faustsage: Der Zauberer Cyprianus'' (Hölder-Pichler-Tempsky, 1927)Rosemary Guiley, ''The encyclopedia of Magic and Alchemy'' (Infobase, 2006; {{ISBN|0-8160-6048-7}}), p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=fkc10_zCBv0C&pg=PA38&dq=cyprianus+magic&hl=en&ei=DTMLTu2hGqKqsAKR1eSnAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CFYQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=cyprianus%20magic&f=false 38] The ''Black Books of Elverum'' claim to be a summary of a ''Cyprianus'' by a "Bishop Johannes Sell" from Oxford, England in 1682. The British bishop [[John Fell (bishop)|John Fell]] may be the person who is meant here; Fell did publish an edition of the works of St. Cyprian.Rustad, p. 1 The actual stories told of Cyprianus in Scandinavia often made no reference to St. Cyprian. Some made Cyprianus into a typical [[Faust]] figure; some said that Cyprianus was a wicked Norwegian or Dane who learned magic through his dealings with the [[Devil]]; one version makes Cyprianus so evil that the Devil threw him out of [[Hell]]; Cyprianus wrote the text to have his revenge. A different and strongly contradictory version explains that Cyprianus was a student who discovered he was attending a diabolical "black school", and wrote the text to explain how to undo all the [[witchcraft]] he learned there.[[Benjamin Thorpe]], ''Northern Mythology: comprising the principal popular traditions and superstitions of Scandinavia, north Germany, and the Netherlands'' (London: Edward Lumley, 1851) v. 2 pp. [https://books.google.com/books?id=TTMMAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA186&source=gbs_toc_r&cad=4#v=onepage&q&f=false 186 et. seq.] [[File:Signekjerring.jpg|thumb|''En Signekjerring'', an 1848 painting by [[Adolph Tidemand]]. The elderly woman is performing the ''støyping'' divination ritual to seek the cause of the child's illness.]]An [[anachronism|anachronistic]] tale told in the printed [[Danish language|Danish]] spell collection ''Oldtidens Sortebog'' ("Old Time Magic Book") makes Cyprianus to have been a pious and beautiful [[Mexico|Mexican]] [[nun]] from the fourteenth century. In a [[gothic novel|gothic]] tale, ''Oldtidens Sortebog'' has Cyprianus cast into a dungeon in 1351. While imprisoned in the dungeon, Cyprianus rends her clothing and commits her magical knowledge to the rags, written in her own blood. Her text was then found in an old castle.Stokker, above; see generally the chapter, "[https://books.google.com/books?id=YfiMGNKxmwUC&pg=PT140&dq=cyprianus+stokker&hl=en&ei=qTkLTuSiE-SosAK3t93GAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCoQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=cyprianus%20stokker&f=false The Black Book]" ==The spells== The spells in the Cyprianus tradition are typical Germanic folk magic: a mixed bag of [[folk remedy|folk remedies]], [[prayer]]s, and actual magic. They resemble the spells of the [[German language]] ''braucherei'', "[[pow-wow (folk magic)|pow-wow]]", and ''[[The Long Lost Friend]]'' traditions. One typical spell to heal a [[sprained ankle]] went: :''Jesus rei over ei hei
Fållån snåva og foten vrei
Jesus steig av og la foten an
som den tilforn var
i namnet Gud, Fader, Sønn, og Helligånd'' ::"Jesus rode over a stony plain.
His horse stumbled, its leg it did sprain.
Jesus dismounted to cure the pain
And made he injury good again.
In the name of God the Father, Son, and Holy Ghost."Stokker, p. 91 The methods of [[Infectious disease|contagion]] and [[transference]] are in use here; a sacred personage in an apocryphal story is confronted with a problem similar to that faced by the actual sufferer, who avails himself of their supernatural aid.Stokker, pp. 90-93 An important aspect of the magical tradition was the performance of [[divination]], often by pouring molten [[lead]] through a hole in a piece of [[flatbread]] into cold water, a practice called ''[[molybdomancy|støyping]]''. Lead scraped from the windows of churches was often used for this purpose. This was done to divine the cause of [[rickets]], which was often thought to be the result of a [[changeling]], a ''huldrabarn'' or ''bytting'', left in the place of a healthy child by the malicious ''[[huldra|huldra-folk]]''. The diviner in this ritual was called a ''signekjerring'', a "blessing crone".Stokker, ch. "Rickets remedies and lore" ==Inexperienced use of the Black Book== The Inexperienced Use of the Black Book is a motif in [[Scandinavian folklore]]. In such legends, a servant, maid or someone else unexpectedly happens to find and read the Black Book, thus summoning the devil, while the owner, often a clergyman, is away. The only way to save oneself is to give the devil [[adynaton|a task that he can’t solve]]: to empty a fjord, to untie all knots in a fishing net, to twist a rope of sand, to row against the wind with a boat filled with empty buckets, etc.. The devil is then kept busy until the expert or the owner of the book returns and exorcises the devil away. It is given an ML (Migratory Legend) number of 3020 and is related to [[Aarne-Thompson]] type 325, "Apprentice and Ghost" and type 565, "The Magic Mill".{{cite book|author=William F. Hansen|title=Ariadne's thread: a guide to international tales found in classical literature|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ezDlXl7gP9oC&pg=PA36|year=2002|publisher=Cornell University Press|isbn=978-0-8014-3670-3|pages=36–38}} ==See also== *[[Galdrabók]] *''[[The Great Book of Saint Cyprian]]'' *[[Hoodoo (folk magic)|Hoodoo]] *[[Sixth and Seventh Books of Moses]] *[[Tycho Brahe days]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Refbegin}} ;textual sources *{{cite book|editor-link=Anton Christian Bang|editor-last= Bang|editor-first=Anton Christia|title=Norske hexeformularer og magiske opskrifter|year=1901-2|place=Kristiania (Oslo, Norway)|publisher=I Commission hos Jacob Dybwad|series=Videnskabsselskabets skrifter: Historisk-filosofiske klasse, No.1|format=|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OhrXAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA1}} {{Refend}} [[Category:Scandinavian folklore]] [[Category:Scandinavian history]] [[Category:Magic (paranormal)]] [[Category:Occult texts]] [[da:Cyprianus]]

'''DNSChanger''' is a [[DNS hijacking]] [[Trojan horse (computing)|Trojan]].<ref>[https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/wdsi/threats/malware-encyclopedia-description?name=trojan:win32/dnschanger.o Trojan:Win32/Dnschanger.O] – Microsoft</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.virustotal.com/en/file/fdde13872caa1a0e1b9331188ca93b8fc424fed43d86d5cf53f6965f6a77184e/analysis/ |title=Antivirus scan for fdde13872caa1a0e1b9331188ca93b8fc424fed43d86d5cf53f6965f6a77184e] at 2017-01-30 04:47:37 UTC – VirusTotal|website=www.virustotal.com}}</ref> The work of an Estonian company known as [[Rove Digital]], the malware infected computers by modifying a computer's [[Domain Name System|DNS]] entries to point toward its own [[DNS_hijacking#Rogue_DNS_server|rogue]] [[name server]]s, which then injected its own advertising into Web pages. At its peak, DNSChanger was estimated to have infected over four million computers, bringing in at least [[United States dollar|US$]]14 million in profits to its operator from fraudulent advertising revenue.<ref name="ars-massive"/>
Both [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] and [[Mac OS X]] variants of DNSChanger were circulated, the latter taking the form of a related Trojan known as [[RSPlug]]. The FBI raided the malicious servers on November 8, 2011,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.trendmicro.com/trendlabs-security-intelligence/esthost-taken-down-biggest-cybercriminal-takedown-in-history/|title=Esthost Taken Down – Biggest Cybercriminal Takedown in History – TrendLabs Security Intelligence Blog|date=9 November 2011|publisher=}}</ref> but they kept the servers up after they captured it to avoid affected users from losing internet access until July 9, 2012.
==Operation== DNSChanger was distributed as a [[drive-by download]] claiming to be a [[video codec]] needed to view content on a Web site, particularly appearing on rogue [[Internet pornography in the United States|pornography sites]]. Once installed, the malware then modified the system's [[Domain Name System]] (DNS) configuration, pointing them to rogue [[name server]]s operated through affiliates of Rove Digital.<ref name="ars-massive"/> These rogue name servers primarily substituted [[Internet marketing|advertising]] on Web pages with advertising sold by Rove. Additionally, the rogue DNS server [[Clickjacking|redirected links]] to certain Web sites to those of advertisers, such as for example, redirecting the [[Internal Revenue Service|IRS]] Web site to that of a [[tax preparation]] company.<ref name=pcworld-dontlose/> The effects of DNSChanger could also spread itself to other computers within a [[Local area network|LAN]] by mimicking a [[DHCP]] server, pointing other computers toward the rogue DNS servers.<ref name=pcworld-dontlose/> In its indictment against Rove, the [[United States Department of Justice]] also reported that the rogue servers had blocked access to update servers for [[antivirus software]].<ref name=ars-sevencharged/>
==Shutdown and interim DNS servers== On October 1, 2011, as part of ''Operation Ghost Click'' (a collaborative investigation into the operation), the [[United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York]] announced charges against six Estonian nationals and one Russian national connected to DNSChanger and Rove Digital for [[wire fraud]], [[computer intrusion]], and [[Conspiracy (crime)|conspiracy]].<ref name=ars-sevencharged>{{cite web|title=Seven charged in malware-driven click fraud case|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2011/11/seven-charged-in-botnet-driven-click-fraud-case/|publisher=Ars Technica|accessdate=6 July 2012}}</ref> Arrests were made by Estonian authorities, and servers connected to the malware located in the United States were seized by the [[FBI]].<ref name=ars-massive>{{cite web|title=How the most massive botnet scam ever made millions for Estonian hackers|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2011/11/how-the-most-massive-botnet-scam-ever-made-millions-for-estonian-hackers/|publisher=Ars Technica|accessdate=6 July 2012}}</ref>
Due to concerns by FBI agents that users still infected by DNSChanger could lose Internet access if the rogue DNS servers were shut down entirely, a temporary [[court order]] was obtained to allow the [[Internet Systems Consortium]] to operate replacement servers, which would serve DNS requests from those who had not yet removed the infection, and to collect information on those still infected in order to promptly notify them about the presence of the malware.<ref name=dnschanger-dark>{{cite web|title=‘DNSChanger’ Malware Could Strand Thousands When Domains Go Dark on Monday|url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2012/07/dns-changer-going-dark/|publisher=Wired|accessdate=6 July 2012}}</ref> While the court order was set to expire on March 8, 2012, an extension was granted until July 9, 2012 due to concerns that there were still many infected computers.<ref name=pcworld-dontlose>{{cite web|title=Don't Lose the Internet in July! FBI Repeats DNSChanger Warning|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2403364,00.asp|publisher=PC World|accessdate=6 July 2012}}</ref> [[F-Secure]] estimated on July 4, 2012 that at least 300,000 computers were still infected with the DNSChanger malware, 70,000 of which were located in the United States. <ref name=pcw-infected>{{cite web|title=Are You Infected With DNSChanger Malware?|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2406720,00.asp|publisher=PC World|accessdate=6 July 2012}}</ref> The interim DNS servers were officially shut down by the FBI on July 9, 2012.<ref name=pcw-impact/>
Impact from the shutdown was considered to be minimal, due in part to major [[Internet service providers]] providing temporary DNS services of their own and support to customers affected by DNSChanger. and informational campaigns surrounding the malware and the impending shutdown. These included online tools that could check for the presence of DNSChanger, while [[Google]] and [[Facebook]] provided notifications to visitors of their respective services who were still affected by the malware.<ref name=pcw-infected/> By July 9, 2012, F-Secure estimated that the number of remaining DNSChanger infections in the U.S. had dropped from 70,000 to 42,000.<ref name=pcw-impact>{{cite web|title=ISPs Report Minimal DNSChanger Impact|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2406855,00.asp|publisher=PC World|accessdate=13 July 2012}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.dcwg.org/ www.dcwg.org] — DNS Changer Working Group; tools and information for diagnosing DNSChanger infections
